pros: - kind coworkers, supporting higher ed's mission, working with college students
cons: - no room for movement within the institution, slow to change

pros: Great students, beautiful campus, progressive community, fantastic union
cons: There is currently almost no HR department, which is symptomatic of large-scale administrative chaos. Admin is a shell. Faculty and staff have to do their jobs, plus run the university, because administrators generally won’t step up, are incompetent, or quit and are never replaced. There’s a terrible pattern of bullying among faculty (faculty to faculty). Great place to be a student; terrible place to work.

pros: I had a great experience working with the people in my office. However, every student's job on campus is unique and largely depends on the management and people you work with.
cons: The wage offered is extremely low and is not enough to sustain a decent living. Additionally, there is a strict limit of 19 hours per week for work.

review_title: There is a lot of free time, but when you need to really work, it can get stressful.
pros: Good boss. Free housing. Being able to connect with a lot of residents.
cons: Busy at beginning and end of year. Employees above resident director level do not care that much about you or residents.

job_title: Student Administrative Assistant in Bellingham, WA

cons: This cannot be your only job - you will need other financial revenues - scholarships are recommended Hours will be limited by the budget

pros: Schedule is pretty much up to you as long as you get the work done.
cons: Pretty much 0 training, dependent on which professor you get.

pros: Good benefits and kind coworkers - especially students and professors

review_title: It's alright - depends on the department

cons: The pay is very low — barely enough to get by. It’s common to receive positions that you know little about and you just adapt quickly.

cons: Once you become director of an office there isn't room for further advancement.

pros: Flexible schedule, great access to library resources which can help in classes.

cons: Budgets tend to be tight and can change significantly. There is also significant overhead in buearacracy.

pros: Faculty is great. Good community. Students are smart and energetic.

review_title: Professionally Stagnating Environment with a Severe of Scholarship, Leadership, and Vision
pros:
- The Campus is beautiful, and the students are some of the most inspiring, creative, and adaptive young minds I've ever met
- The President and Board share strategic plan and initiative which seem ambitious and could someday set a foundation for a world-class institution
- Once you're in, you're in... almost to a fault
cons:
- Underwhelming faculty (mediocre research if any)
- Severe lack of leadership throughout administrative levels
- Resistance to technological adaptations and/or failure to standardize
- Lack of evidence-based decision making
- Institutional "Inbreeding" (Many people who work here, went here, in disciplines unrelated to their professional needs)
- Poor H
R Department Advocacy for Employee Health and Satisfaction
- Severe lack of transparency
- "Siloing" which leads to loss of productivity in student services
- "We've always done it this way" attitude, despite evidence of inefficacy
- Poor organization and management structures
- Low Pay relative to cost-of-living
- Job Duties often required outside of scope of employment contract
- Myopic Vision from administrative leadership
- High Staff Turnover

job_title: Program Support Staff In Extended Education in Bellingham, WA
pros:
I worked with international students on the side. I loved working with them and creating life long relationships, helping them with their daily needs, and learning more about different cultures. The students are what kept me there. 

I also worked in the office at the front desk handling phone calls for different Extended Education programs. 

I had a lot of support from administrators who worked with Youth Programs, ALL, WesternOnline, etc. 

I had a lot of support with other administrators not part of Language and culture programs.
cons:
Language and culture programs is currently failing and not bringing in enough students for numerous reasons. Largest reason is because of the administrators. 

Lots of transitions are currently occurring. 
Current administrators failed to respect and cooperate with two female administrators. 
Slow turn back for visas and for assisting students. 
It's not really a part of the university...its a business on the side for the university. 
Most student staff have to quit upon graduation. 
You can only work 19 hours per week per university rules; its not enough to pay rent. Most weeks I worked over 20 hours and you have to put hours onto the next time sheet or the university will be in trouble (technically if university students work over 19 hours a week at $13, they would all be on welfare....).

review_title: Great immediate coworkers and supervisor, poor higher level management
job_title: Assistant Resident Director in Bellingham, WA
pros: This position, despite requirements that are constantly in flux, provides a lot of opportunities to acquire professional skills that I would not have gained in other times during my college years. My relationship to my Resident Director and the Resident Advisers is the best part, as staffs work so closely together and grow to depend on and really trust one another. My Resident Director also invested a lot of time in helping me succeed in academics and preparing for post-college life, which has been very helpful.
cons: The upper administration of this department has a hard time accepting responsibility for its mistakes and too often disregards serious feedback from RAs and ARDs. Especially this year, when there were many incidents that resulted in severely negative outcomes, we saw very little actual change from the higher levels of administration that control systemic change. For me, this directly impacted the community in which I worked, and while the immediate staff was very supportive of one another, the upper administration did not respond appropriately.

pros: Some of the positive aspects of working at Western Washington University was the work hours, employees, and work environment. The shift was only three hours long, which was perfect for a part time job. My fellow employees and supervisor were mostly friendly and encouraging. The work expected of me was easily explained and easy to handle.
cons: The few downsides to working as an employee for WWU was the shifting positions and supervisors. The first quarter I worked as a student janitor, I was assigned to a supervisor who spoke little English and was hard to understand, as well as impatient and easily annoyed. Thankfully, I was reassigned to a second supervisor who was much clearer and understanding. However, it was located much farther away and was hard for me to reach in time for my shift compared to the closer location of my previous position.

review_title: Western is a Great Place to Work
pros: WWU is one of the best employers in Bellingham. Compensation is (so I hear) low relative to other universities, but for Bellingham, it's very good. For benefited employees, the benefits are great, especially if your position is exempt. Staff in many cases have it better than faculty when it comes to overall compensation (other than tenured faculty of course). Work-life balance is understood, so it's a great workplace for someone with a family.
cons: The normal schedule is 8AM to 5PM. That can be difficult for people with young children in school; but with the right supervisor and the right kind of position, a different start time can often be negotiated. Many positions are part-time and have no benefits; but positions open up quite frequently and once you're "in" at Western, you're encouraged to apply for positions when they become available.

review_title: WWU is a nice campus, but crappy place to work
job_title: Information Technology Specialist in Bellingham, WA
pros: College environment, beautiful campus, nice community, wide range of positions, energetic student body, smaller town atmosphere, informal casual working environment for most positions
cons: Poor salary compared to similar positions elsewhere, 0 possibility for advancement, poor upper management/administration, incompetent HR department, excessive internal politics, poor/non-existent peer review process

pros: Its a steady job and it really depends on which area you work in. everyone is very friendly. The city is amazing, especially if you love the outdoors! they have some perks at WWU like really cheap fitness classes and gym access. You also can get a tuition waiver if you are looking to increase your education.
cons: The university is under resourced and they wont put the money/ time back into you as an employee. Western as a whole does with the things mentioned in "pros", but not your supervisors. They just don't have the money to do so. It has an extremely prevalent hierarchy. They try to fit 2 FTE into 1.

pros: The atmosphere, the people, the culture, and the experience were all unforgettable. I was able to really delve into the Western culture and really get an understanding of the people and students I was working with. Even in such a professional environment, I was able to use my creativity in order to find better solutions for organization, and keep the office in good spirits. The people within my office, including my boss, helped to work with my schedule to provide maximum hours while not overwhelming me.
cons: On some occasions I had to deal with difficult students who were always trying to find loop-holes around our protocol. It was extremely frustrating to deal with those individuals and others who felt they were in a position of authority.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: Working as a TA gives you a ton of opportunity to refocus on the work that you already saw within your major, work alongside your professors as a networking opportunity, and help students below your year with some of the things you might have struggled with at the time. Generally you're working with professors within your major, who understand your workload, and are more than willing to work with you to make sure the TA job doesn't impact your studies.
cons: You're likely not going to be paid a ton to do it -- if your financial aid isn't sufficient to live off of you might consider a different job.

pros: As a TA at Western, you have lots of chances to communicate with different people. You will have connections with professors and students. You can use your knowledge and experience to help other people, which could be a very acommplishment for you when you see others' success. You can enroll health insurance with Western if you want to. Professors (your supervisors) and coworkers (your classmate, sometimes) are the ones that you are very familiar with, it is very comfortable to work as a TA.
cons: Some of the classes that you assist might take more time to handle, such as grading, preparation, or office hours.

pros: Western staff and faculty were consistently some of the friendliest and caring people I've worked with. I loved my position as a student employee because my work was appreciated, I felt like I was making an impact on the department, and my boss was so flexible. The staff recognized the fact that student workers are students first, and this flexibility and work life balance was a huge advantage.
cons: I can't think of any cons aside from the fact that student employees lose their positions once they graduate—otherwise I might have stayed in beautiful Bellingham!

pros:
Great facilities. An abundance of processing equipment as well as characterization instruments at your disposal. The professors are around all summer and are incredibly helpful. They love helping interns.
The buss system in the city is fantastic. quick and easy to figure out, and well maintained.
cons:
Parking. The only parking available is a big gravel parking lot at one end of campus. If you are driving, your car will get dirty.
The Engineering building could use some renovation.

job_title: IT Specialist II in Bellingham, WA
pros:
There are some very solid departments within Western, I am lucky enough to work for one.
- Solid mentorship
- Good exposure to new skills
- Good community
cons:
- Pay is about 30% less than other Whatcom jobs in my field and about 50% less than seattle jobs. Management would say that benefits make up the difference, but other companies offer similar benefits. 
- Some departments are very adverse to change
- Faculty can sometimes prove challenging to work with
- Age demographic is on the older side

pros: Supervisors were very understanding of employee difficulties, committed to improving the quality of the services offered by the tutoring center, and devoted to helping their employees succeed after moving on to other jobs. I'm very, very, very glad I worked here.
cons: You'll get mandatory training about how college is supposed to be a "safe-space" for all fifty-thousand genders.

review_title: Great job for resume building as a student
job_title: Orientation Student Advisor in Bellingham, WA
pros: I learned a lot about myself & what I wanted to pursue my degree in when I worked as an Orientation Student Advisor through the New Student Services & Family Outreach Office. They let me work on and off for two years, picking up a few hours a quarter for random events which I thought was awesome. This job specifically looked pretty good on my resume as a recent grad. Plus it was a super fun job and honestly contributed to my overall great experience as a student at WWU.
cons: Minimum wage, but that is to be expected. Made up for it by offering a lot of paid meals and/or housing.

review_title: Western and Bellingham - A Great Combination
pros: Western is a great academic institution that is clearly focused on developing its students.  There is a very strong sense of community, much more so than at other universities I have been a part of.  It is a great place to work, and a great place to live because it is located in one the most beautiful parts of the country.
cons: There are some longtime employees who can be negative.  Not matter what is done for them they are not happy.  Bellingham could be more progressive.

job_title: Research Compliance Officer in Bellingham, WA
pros: I believe that WWU is a good academic institution that is devoted to intellectual development and research opportunities for both its students and its employees.  The employees are provided with great benefits, a great health and wellness program, and transparent administration.  The institution prioritizes quality teaching while still providing a quality research environment.
cons: Too many professors are being asked to teach heavy loads since many of the adjuncts have lost their jobs and open faculty lines have been eliminated when professors retire.  My position has been reduced to half-time to save money because of the tough economic times. Everyone is working harder in these lean economic times.

review_title: (Restek)Fun coworkers and challenging work but less than optimal pay.
pros:
As a student employee you get to work with lots of your peers who have similar interests.
Through various projects there is as much room for personal growth as you want to put in.
The school/work balance is also really good, because you are a student first before you are an employee. Your schedule will revolve around when you are not in class and if school is getting rough you can just talk to your boss and simply work less.
cons:
The pay is really sub-optimal for the work that you do. Just slightly over min.
There are no real benifits for student employees(no free food, personal computers, etc.).

review_title: Helping students with all aspects of school work
pros:
- Room for growth
- Learn more than you expect & can apply it to yourself
- Works around your school schedule
cons:
- Low pay
- Racist hypocritical managers
- Half the staff doesn’t actually work
- Not enough training for everyone so people go in teaching other students wrong things and hurt their grades/waste a lot of their time.
- Only 4 people get promoted per entering class, if you stay pay increases by just a $1
- Can hardly get more than 10hours of work after your first quarter

pros: Flexible scheduling, fun events to photograph, ability to share ideas, respectful management, creative assignments, great coworkers and supervisor, responsive management, wonderful work environment
cons: Not enough hours for me to really make a difference in my income. This department (Canadian/American Studies) only had a few events and awards ceremonies each quarter and so my hours were very low. This was difficult being a student, but it was nice to have a flexible schedule around my classes.

pros: I really enjoyed working here for a number of reasons: great coworkers, great location, always busy, and great students. I will miss WWU!
cons: There are not many opportunities for advancement, unfortunately.  People work in their same positions for many, many years.  Also, budget cuts make some of the jobs a bit less stable.

review_title: Office Politics Required, Questions Will Result in Release
job_title: Student Advisor, Office Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Beautiful campus, some passionate faculty, involved community, critical thinking still alive in liberal arts, libraries are great resources, good education and health programs for staff.
cons: Supervisors were demeaning despite inherent authority. Plenty of office gossip. No willingness to provide performance feedback. Shady dispersion of contract duties. No check on use of supervisory authority. Staff seems bored and uninspired, petty aggressions abound. Staffers lied and abused authority when questioned about standards.

pros: The student staff is always positive and the professional staff is encouraging and supportive of making job experience as a student relevant after graduation.
cons: There is a lot of disorganization and miscommunication between different departments and it is able to get messy extremely quickly.

pros: Student employees enjoy the benefit of gaining experience in a professional environment while having support and understanding from management regarding an individuals pursuit toward academic excellence.
cons: Working within some areas of the university there is a form of peer pressure made obvious regarding the attendence of events held by different departments and clubs.

pros: As a tutor they were very flexible with scheduling around classes.  The  community and the students were both outstanding.  I gained in knowledge through the process.
cons: I think compensation could be a bit higher for the content we were providing for other students.  If students had to get their own tutors, they would have had to pay at least 2.5 times what we were making.

job_title: Lab Research Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros:
Hands on work. 
Program experience.  
Gaining knowledge of identification methods for an array of different organisms. 
Flexible hours. 
Great, like-minded staff members. 
Ability to be apart of several different research projects.
cons: Logging data can be a long and tedious process. Identification was fun and hands on, but can be a lot of the same thing depending on the project. Inputting the data into spreadsheets is the very tedious aspect of the job that one could without.

job_title: Graphic Designer (Associated Students Publicity Center) in Bellingham, WA
pros: Working as a graphic designer (within the Associated Students), the experience of working on client projects while being a student is very valuable. The hours are flexible and the advisers make good references for post graduate jobs.
cons: Salaried positions pay less than you can make as an hourly employee, and you may be expected to do more than you are really being paid for. The advisers are also stretched thin between bureaucratic meetings and handling the high turnover rate.

job_title: Student Admissions Representative in Bellingham, WA
pros: As a tour guide I was able to meet the most amazing people, work environment was very relaxed and enjoyable, flexible working hours. I got paid for having a lot of fun and giving tours which was the most fun job I have ever had.
cons: Office of admissions management can be very dramatic. Working in the actual office seems like it would involve a lot of gossip. Tour guide managers seem to have forgotten what its like to actually give tours

job_title: Information Desk Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: The job I worked at had a great atmosphere and flexible hours. Very understanding upper management when there are problems. Overall the experience there was great especially since I was a student as well while working for the university.
cons: They would frequently hire new people for the specific area I was working at and sometimes there would be disagreements with the new recruits. It rarely happens and a lot of the time people who supervise the job will make sure there is not bad blood between co-workers.

pros: Flexible hours, works with your schedule. Understanding staff.  Very independent work, hours are recorded independently and tutoring sessions are scheduled between you and student.
cons: Not enough hours, not a substantial amount but good for a part time gig while in school. You'll get the most work during finals week because everyone waits until the last minute, making tutoring impossible and not worth it.

pros: Working for a university which makes a difference in students lives is a very rewarding experience. Having a job here has helped me understand the effort it takes to run a university.
cons: There are only so many jobs you can work in before you run out of moves. Outside candidates are considered for jobs which makes it harder to move up in the organization.

review_title: Fair compensation for what is expected
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Tuition waiver is a life saver, with that and the stipend i can afford a modest life in Bellingham as I persue my degree. Health insurance is surprisingly good, it's just the standard student insurance plan.
cons: No insurance during summer. The pay us less than some bigger state universities, but considering cost of living it is justifiable. After tyition waiver there are normally still ~$400 quarter in fees.

review_title: great place to work for, genuinely  nice people to work with.
pros:
- Nice co workers
- School holidays, down times during student holidays
- Cheap housing in the region
- Great campus
cons:
- there isnt really a down side to working at WWU, however, the salary of a public university may not be very competitive.
- information is public

pros: Beautiful area, great campus, committed colleagues and supportive staff. So much to take advantage of both on campus and off that it's hard not to want to stay forever.
cons: Very low pay compared to similarly sized universities. Great if you like rain and 45 degree weather 80% of the year.

pros: Pay and benefits were very good. Beautiful campus.
cons: Legacy employees, lack of trust between workers and management. VERY resistant to change or outsiders coming into the university. Need to stop hiring relatives and friends, that is the diversity issue on campus pertaining to employees. Military and Conservatives not welcomed.

pros: Some really great people to work with!
cons: Higher ed really isn't my gig. WWU feels like it's trapped in a bubble, - lots of people who come & don't want to leave Bellingham. The university touts its excellence & quality but they feel very old school & stagnant. Everything is pretty good there, which actually feels like part of the challenge.

pros: The job helped me work on my own academic skills and brush up on basic math concepts, it was a great place to work as a student at WWU - I always had holidays and breaks off, as well as Saturdays.
cons: Tutoring the same subject became very repetitive and the hours were very sporadic i.e. one hour shifts, or working for an hour or two, having a couple hour gap and then having another hour scheduled.

pros:
Great university to be a part of.
Good people who care about their jobs and do excellent work.
Unions and good benefits.
cons: The structure is hierarchical and sometimes it is difficult to get things accomplished. Be prepared to be patient if you want to get things moving forward.

pros: Great environment.  Relaxed, easy to talk to individuals.  Low stress most of the time.  The pay could be better for technical jobs, but it seems like it's fair for the public sector.
cons: Being a Student Employee, at times you may not be given access that would make your job easier.  These include, set of keys, or certain computer privileges.  Some employees have the "just clock in and out" mentality.

pros: They don't pay well, but work with your schooling hours very nicely, and gives some experience to put on a resume.
cons: They don't pay well, not much guidance, and many of the stuff you find yourself doing you end up looking up how do do on your own.

pros: The campus is beautiful, the buildings are new/renovated and the people are down-to-earth. The university is well organized and the administration divisions work efficiently -- unusual for an university.
cons: The wages are somewhat lower compared to other universities and parking can be a drag at times.

review_title: Work Study Student at Digital Media Center
job_title: Digital Media Center Staff in Bellingham, WA
pros:
-You get to work out your hours.
- Lots of learning opportunities
-Fun environment
-Access to a studio
-Great for resume
-The boss is kind and fun
cons: -Like any work study student at WWU, you can only work up to 19hrs a week

pros: The campus is pleasant, small enough to walk across, and clean; good benefits; Bellingham is a nice place to live with good public transportation.
cons: Depends on the department. In some cases (such as mine) women were cut out of the loop on important matters. Little or no real support from administration.

review_title: Great mission, difficult to make things happen
pros: Students and faculty are amazing, most of the leadership is incredible - including the president. It's a great university with a sound missions.
cons: Some employees are underperforming, others are downright unprofessional and nearly impossible to get rid of under union protection.

review_title: They're Making me do this to use the site
pros: State work benefits, Good Union, Positive work environment, competent leadership (at least in Academic Custodial - though the overall leadership of the college is also reasonably competent).
cons: They make you pay for parking, so subtract about $300 from whatever you're supposed to be making unless you're in walking/bus distance.

pros: Great supervisors who will guide you and help you when you have any questions. Working at the Wade King Student Recreation Center is a fun, straight-forward job.
cons: Can get boring. Not to challenging. Don't let this scare you off though, it's a perfect job for an entry-level student who wants fitness or aquatic experience on their resume.

pros: The work is relatively easy but not so dull as to unmotivate.  The pay is great. Also, it gives you little but some experience communicating in a leadership role
cons: Repetitive work, also not as many hours as I'd like.  Job is only scheduled in the short term, meaning low job security.

pros: Everyone who I work with at the University is nice, pretty welcoming and the job I had was pretty relaxed.
cons: As a student employee you are only paid minimum wage and can't work more than 19 hours a week. So I had to get an additional job to make ends meet.

review_title: I was a graduate teaching assistant in the Department of Mathematics for the 2013-2014 school year (3 quarters).
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Math TAs get a two-week training course and check-up meetings once per week during the first quarter. Lead instructors can be extremely helpful and supportive.
cons: Lead instructors can also be unhelpful. Fortunately this was not my experience.

pros: Flexibility towards a students schedule and needs, positive reinforcement, an educational work environment that's inclusive instead of exclusive
cons: Lack of communication between faculty members/departments

pros:
I had a great team to work with 
My supervisor had a good understanding of my high work load
Good communication with supervisor
cons: It was hard to manage being a part-time TA and going to Graduate school full time. Sometimes my job included coming in on weekends to get the work done.

pros: The pay is good and the people are friendly. It is relatively easy to get time off.
cons: There is a lot of overtime and it can be hard to have a healthy work-life balance

review_title: Western is a Great Place to Work
pros: The campus is beautiful, the instructors are helpful, and working for Western gives me the flexibility to be a student employee with a flexible job.
cons: Western administration, as with other large organizations, can take a good amount of time to make decisions and implement policies.

review_title: Great people to work with, very flexible.
pros: Flexible with work schedule around class schedule. You get to speak with your peers and help them out. Sometimes you get to do homework while you work.
cons: The work can get monotonous.

pros: Super fun atmosphere, some awesome people work in the department, and overall great student job.
cons: Change in shift rules has put somewhat of a downer to the working environment.

review_title: Graduate Assistant  Jobs for Biomechanics Lab
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: New laboratories and building, all current and updated equipment for research and teaching. Very good faculty, masters Exercise Science program is well-rounded and challenging.
cons: Depending on the cohort you have, class work can be difficult with time management of classwork load and thesis project.

pros: The professional library staff have been unfailingly pleasant to work with.
cons: The shortage in permanent library staff means that the library doesn't always have enough human resources to fulfill the missions it outlines. However, everybody who is employed makes a clear and meaningful effort to do their part.

pros: Flexible hours, low stress, friendly faculty. Great opportunity for extra practice and a good way to gain exposure to experiences you normally wouldn't have access to.
cons: There's more work to be done during the times your own class coursework intensifies. Few if any opportunities offered to move around.

review_title: Easy Sudent Job with Lots of Perks
pros: I love this job! My supervisors are really kind and supportive. We self-schedule, so it is easy to work around academic obligations. You get to work a lot of really cool events!
cons: Hours are variable, so not a reliable source of income.

pros: Vibrant and energized culture and community.
cons: Left because there was no upward mobility and was under compensated for the value I provided.

pros: Decent benefits package.  Excellent view of Bellingham Bay. Close to Canada, Mt Baker, and outdoor recreation abounds.
cons: Low salaries. High cost of living in this area. Challenges for finding meaningful work for spouses/partners.

pros: The campus is beautiful, the student energy can be contagious
cons: Office politics are a constant. It’s hard to get to know your coworkers because it’s so clique-ish. Policies apply only to some people

pros: Very flexible hours to work around classes. I worked in the general chemistry labs, everyone was very friendly and helpful. Overall an excellent job to have while also juggling a busy class schedule.
cons: Chemistry department lab safety is not well enforced or monitored

review_title: One of the best student jobs I've ever had
job_title: Program Support Staff in Bellingham, WA
pros:
There were lots of opportunity to take on extra responsibilities. I
I learned valuable management skills.
Comfortable leaning environment.
Flexible with student schedules.
cons:
At times they expected too much from a part time position. 
Not many opportunities to increase pay.

pros: Benefits such as pension, days off, and pay is good.
cons: Non-progressive environment, something that should take 1 day takes weeks, political and unprofessional.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Bellingham, WA
pros: Western, while it has its shortcomings like many higher ed institutes, strives for innovation and excellence and is open to change.
cons: Because it is not a research institute, there is less focus on output of research and more on teaching.

job_title: Faculty Administrative Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: They are understanding if you are  a student and willing to work with your school schedule in mind.
cons: Do expect that during intersession there to be little to no work.

review_title: Great Place to Work; Pro Staff Log Tremendous Hours
pros: The University environment is challenging and friendly. Most staff are highly respectful and engage in intelligent conversation.
cons: Limited career path growth opportunities. Expectations on Professional Staff are significantly higher than Classified Staff creating an imbalance.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: You get paid to teach, and covers most of your school charges, completely covers tuition
cons: Health care options could be better, pay has been fairly stagnant over the past decade, though they did raise it last year for most TAs.

job_title: Study Group Tutor in Bellingham, WA
pros:
Easy, and fun
Awesome experience for educational purposes
cons:
Students complaining
Not enough hours
Students think you are teacher

pros:
- Easy to find a job if you're a student
- Flexible schedules at most jobs
cons: - The University has recently put a pay freeze on all student jobs, effectively halting all wage increases for student employees

pros: Student-oriented culture.  Most divisions have supportive culture and empowerment for employees.  Creativity, innovation and even eccentricity valued.
cons: Limited state and private funding with lots of ups and downs.  The downs mean RIFs.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Flexible schedule depending on research advisor, flexible TA hours, fast paced graduation in most departments, funding offered in most STEM labs
cons: Little to no options for TA assignments in STEM departments, TA compensation is quite low

pros: Very flexible schedule and a very friendly work environment.
cons: It requires some time to get to know the people you work with. Once you get that, you will enjoy working there.

pros: Excellent benefits and perks (free coffee, employee wellness program), relaxed work atmosphere and flexible schedules, supportive team members, helpful HR training sessions.
cons: Often difficult to innovate / senior leadership stuck.

pros: I am given a lot of freedom in how I accomplish my tasks, along with clear goals.
cons: The pay rate isn't great, but it is an entry level position, and good experience.

job_title: EXPERIENCE Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kirkland, WA
pros: Good environment to grow and learn how to teach math. You are supported with wonderful experienced instructors.
cons: It can be rough jumping into teaching to quickly and managing your own classes.

job_title: Grad Student TA in Bellingham, WA
pros: Some of the professors are great
cons: The administration does not care about grad students

job_title: AS Communications Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: great team work, culture, and encouraged to grow both professionally and personally.
cons: too many bureaucratic procedures

pros: Wonderful setting, lovely city to be located in, competitive academic nature for students
cons: adjunct faculty aren't offered as many benefits as they should have

pros: Good travel opportunities, fun job overall, very student focused
cons: No room for growth in department, people will not take you seriously and expect you to leave within 3 years

review_title: Met my expectations but wasn't impressed.
job_title: Business Calculus Study Group Facilitator in Bellingham, WA
pros: beautiful campus, a lot of freedom in how we structured our sessions.
cons: many students don't care, it's just a class they have to pass.

review_title: A great experience with an energetic atmoshpere.
pros: Excellent energy with employees, strong culture, and fast-paced environment.
cons: Hours are limited due to student employment.

pros: Improved communication skills, gained knowledge using CRC and banner systems, lots of customer service experience in person and on the phone
cons: no room to grow in company

pros: Flexible hours, social job, able to choose schedule, pay increases the longer you work there
cons: No medical benefits, not a lot of room to move up

pros:
- Relaxed environment
- Seeing that you are having an impact
- Surrounded by students
- Works around class schedule
cons: - Payed minimum wage. That is pretty much it.

job_title: Writer/Editor for Extended Education in Bellingham, WA
pros: Excellent experience  (writing/public relations)
cons: Extremely low wage. This job is great but for the work I put in, the pay is terrible

pros:
Worked with School Schedule
Good way to meet peers
cons: Not very many hours available

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Working as an undergradate teaching assistant in a lab was so rewarding and a very good experience
cons: you have to like working with your peers

review_title: Lots of resources but lots of hoops to jump to get anything done
job_title: Social Media Coordinator in Bellingham, WA
pros: Loved connecting with other departments and offices on campus
cons: Lacking communication between teams and offices

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Great people, for the most part
cons: Discovered that some professors lose their professionalism once you enter into research

pros: Easy to attend classes and hold office hours for those students that need attention.
cons: Being on campus all day

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst/Programmer in Bellingham, WA
pros: Work Environment, and impact on the world is wonderful
cons: Pay is poor compared to other options. No advancement options.

pros: Good management and friendly staff.
cons: Close knit employees so can feel intimidating when you first start.

job_title: Financial Aid Peer Advisor in Bellingham, WA
pros: Amazing staff, friendly, easy going boss, talking
cons: Some students can be a pain

pros: Supportive supervisors, good pay, flexible hours if part time, good benefits if you’re not a temp
cons: Lots of coworkers you never meet

job_title: Work Study Student in Bellingham, WA
pros:
Very Flexible with schedule
Great employees
Very easy work
cons: N/A, very good place to work

pros: Great pay and I was generally left alone when it came to decision making.
cons: Lack of communication from upper management.

pros: Fantastic faculty, Great program with lots of learning.
cons: I can not think of any bad things about this program.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Good pay and able to work on my own schedule.
cons: Expectations vary by professor which can lead to miscommunication, etc.

pros: Good work environment, learn many techniques, good professors
cons: Not very high caliber science, not that great compensation, not much room for advancement.

pros: Great people, great benefits, great place.
cons: Pay is lower than market rates, but the benefits probably make up for it.

pros: Work very well with students and had great benefits.
cons: Strong work connection built maybe hard to feel completely welcome.

pros: Very good place to work
cons: Nothing bad to say about this place

pros:
Flexible
Stable
Nice Benefits
Good Work Environment

flex schedule
MBA tuition paid for
decent salary for amount of time spent at work

job_title: Financial Aid Peer Advisor in Bellingham, WA
pros: Flexible Hours, Work-study Job, Great Colleagues and holiday grazes,
cons: No cons for this job

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Very flexible, Opportunity to  learn

job_title: Student Admission Representative in Bellingham, WA
pros:
- Mobility to move upwards 
- Flexible scheduling as a student

pros: Great Benefits, decent wages, and academic environment.
cons: weather in Bellingham, cold and rainy.  not fun

pros: good work life balance, understand that we're students first and employees second

pros: liberal and social science college education

pros: Great atmosphere, benefits, overall good experience.

pros: Good friendly atmosphere, appreciated the type of business.
cons: Nothing to report that were CONS

pros: Good coworkers, great learning environment.
cons: Hours are just ok and the pay is basically minimum wage.

pros: Good community to work with

pros:
Get to learn a wide range of job skills.
Fun staff and environment.
cons: Future planning can be flexible.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Bellingham, WA
pros: Flexible schedule, decent pay, dedicated to inclusivity
cons: No PTO, small teams, little work structure

pros: very flexible, laid back, nice to work with other students
cons: only about 8 hours a week

pros: Great work environment, able to set my own schedule.

job_title: Help Desk Technician in Seattle, WA

pros: Inclusive, good for organizers, dynamic office

pros: Tuition waver, flexible schedule with professor
